title: Fierce tornado with 111mph winds and 'golf ball-sized' hail rips houses apart in Texas

A relentless Tornado and its 111 MPH winds tore through part of Texas, ripping people's lives apart by destroying homes and vehicles.

Buildings were levelled as cars were tossed into the sky in Dallas as fear gripped the state.

The National Weather Service warned of "a life-threatening situation" and that "complete destruction" was possible - and it wasn't kind on the residents.

The Tornado knocked out power to more than 175,000 homes and businesses before bringing down houses.

The mega storm left what was described as a "miles-long swath of destruction" through Dallas.

(Image: Twitter/Billy Frank Watkins Jr.)

(Image: Twitter/@NorthTXWeather)

Incredibly only minor injuries have so far been reported.

“It was exactly one tornado that hit at 9:02 pm,” emergency responder David Roth told the Dallas Morning News newspaper.

“We also saw golf-ball and baseball-sized hail in some areas and a narrow swath of north Dallas that got between 1 to 3 inches of rain."

All tornado warnings have now been lifted and there are no flash flood warnings.

Resident Tina Devlin said her home was a "total loss."

(Image: @AthenaRising/@Weatherkannon)

"I heard all the snapping of the trees and the wind blowing, and so I climbed into this bedroom closet, and just as I got in there, the roof blew off," she told NBC Dallas-Fort Worth.

Lew Morris, one of the hosts of Reckless Rock Radio, said in a Facebook message that the power at the station went out first, followed by the "distinctive whistle" of a tornado soon after.

"We then heard the building shaking and could hear the glass windows shattering everywhere along with debris banging around - we waited until all the noise died down," Morris said.

(Image: Chip Somodevilla/POOL/EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock)

"We walked out to see the studio he was just broadcasting from destroyed."

Former US President George W. Bush and his wife Laura live in the area but a representative of the family told NBC News they were "safe and praying for their neighbours".

Northwest Arkansas Regional Airport said flights were still departing but security screenings were being done manually.
description: It ravaged Dallas, Texas, with many left having to rebuild their lives but no deaths or serious injuries have been reported
